articles.title: The Perilous Path to Escape Gaza City
articles.content: Gazans have had to load up their lives in search of refuge multiple times throughout the war. As thousands were forced to flee again this week, a Times photographer joined them heading south.

articles.title: Zinc Roofs Give Paris Its Signature Look. But They Are a Nightmare in Heat.
articles.content: As climate change helps fuel more severe heat waves, the city is struggling between maintaining its architectural heritage and keeping apartments livable.

articles.title: Opposition to Putin Pulls Up European Leaders Dragged Down at Home
articles.content: The foreign policy successes of Keir Starmer of Britain, Emmanuel Macron of France and Friedrich Merz of Germany are in contrast with their dismal domestic performances.

articles.title: Secret Report Undercuts U.K. Condemnations of Palestine Action Group
articles.content: The British government banned Palestine Action under an antiterrorism law, but an intelligence document said most of its activity “would not be classified as terrorism.”

articles.title: In the Pacific, Unkept U.S. Promises on Climate Cut Deep
articles.content: Pacific island nations have seen American pledges and attention come and go with geopolitical winds. Recent U.S. pullbacks are met with disappointment but not surprise.

articles.title: Bolsonaro was Sentenced to 27 Years for Plotting a Coup in Brazil. What Comes Next?
articles.content: Jair Bolsonaro was sentenced to 27 years in prison for conspiring to cling to power after losing the 2022 elections.

articles.title: Former Judge Sushila Karki Named Nepal’s Leader After Gen Z Protests
articles.content: Sushila Karki, a former chief justice, was the choice of the student protesters whose mass rallies led to violent clashes and toppled the government.

articles.title: Why Dozens of Gleaming S.U.V.s Were Gifted to an Island Nation
articles.content: All around Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands and host of a regional summit, are not-so-subtle hints of donor nations competing for hearts and minds.

articles.title: A Defender of Darkness in the Darkest Place on Earth
articles.content: A Chilean astronomer has become dedicated to battling light pollution in the Atacama Desert and preserve what is considered the best place on Earth to study space.

articles.title: Supporters of Ukraine Anti-Corruption Investigator Call His Jailing Absurd
articles.content: The case of a detective who activists say was investigating close associates of President Volodymyr Zelensky is seen as a bellwether.

articles.title: NATO Steps Up Defenses After Russian Drones Violate Polish Airspace
articles.content: Increased air patrols, air defense systems and other protections will be mobilized over Eastern Europe.

articles.title: Freed South Korean Workers Return From the U.S. to Tearful Cheers
articles.content: The workers, whose detention in a workplace immigration sweep set off outrage in South Korea, expressed both relief and anger.

articles.title: Qatar Prime Minister to Meet Trump Officials After Israeli Strikes in Doha
articles.content: President Trump is said to be planning a meeting with Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani in New York on Friday, after an attack that has rattled Persian Gulf states.

articles.title: Nepal’s Capital Is Choked With Smoke and Gripped by Fear
articles.content: With institutions burned to the ground and the army in control, Gen Z protesters are pushing for an anti-corruption crusader to be appointed as the country’s interim leader.

articles.title: Prince Harry Meets War Veterans in Surprise Visit to Ukraine
articles.content: The prince arrived in Kyiv on his second trip to the country this year. The visit comes after his charity supporting wounded soldiers said it would expand post-conflict rehabilitation.

articles.title: Bolsonaro Convicted of Attempting a Coup in Brazil, Sentenced to 27 Years in Prison
articles.content: Brazil’s Supreme Court convicted the former president of trying to cling to power after losing the 2022 election, including a plan to assassinate his opponent.

articles.title: Nepal’s New Government Calls Elections. Its Critics Cry Foul.
articles.content: Sushila Karki, a former Supreme Court chief justice who was appointed as interim leader, made speed a priority in a process that other jurists deem unconstitutional.

articles.title: Brazil Defies Trump’s Demands by Convicting Bolsonaro
articles.content: Latin America’s largest nation is shaping up as a test case on how to defy President Trump.

articles.title: ‘You Burned This Country Down’: After Arsons, Nepal Reckons With Its Future
articles.content: The frenzy of arson that blazed nationwide this week as protests spread added to those suffering acute burns in a country where fires maim and kill with shocking regularity.

articles.title: As Sabotage in Europe Mounts, So Do Calls to Retaliate Against Russia
articles.content: Drones in Poland and GPS jamming attributed to Russia have intensified a debate over whether the West should impose stiffer penalties for such “hybrid warfare.”

articles.title: Extreme Heat Spurs New Laws Aimed at Protecting Workers Worldwide
articles.content: Governments around the world are enacting measures to try to protect workers from the dangers of heat stress. They’re barely keeping up with the risks.

articles.title: Trump Administration Questions Colombia’s Anti-Drug Efforts and Weighs Cutting Aid
articles.content: Millions in military and development funds for Colombia hang in the balance as Washington questions the country’s fight against cocaine.

articles.title: A Chaotic Showdown Over Election Integrity in India
articles.content: Opposition parties say a move by India’s election commission is part of a wider pattern of election influencing by the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, which derides the claims.

articles.title: 7.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Russia’s Far East
articles.content: The quake briefly triggered tsunami alerts at nearby coastlines, less than two months after a larger earthquake sent tsunami waves across the Pacific.

articles.title: Tesla Board Chair Defend’s Elon Musk’s Humongous Pay Proposal
articles.content: Robyn Denholm, normally media shy, is campaigning to get shareholders to back the chief executive’s trillion-dollar compensation package.

articles.title: Unusual Climate Case Accusing Oil Giants of Racketeering Is Dismissed
articles.content: Citing laws more commonly used against organized crime, the lawsuit argued that fossil fuel companies were responsible for devastating hurricane damage in Puerto Rico.

articles.title: What We Know About Bolsonaro’s Conviction
articles.content: Brazil’s top court convicted former President Jair Bolsonaro on charges of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 presidential election. Ana Ionova, reporting from Brasília, explains the charges and what comes next.

articles.title: Amid Drought, Some U.K. Residents Fume as Blackstone C.E.O. Fills Private Lake
articles.content: A local water company said tankers of its water would no longer be sent to the American billionaire’s estate to fill his lake.

articles.title: Belgian Authorities Say $10 Million Supply of Birth Control Has Not Yet Been Destroyed
articles.content: Contraceptives bought by U.S.A.I.D. have been in limbo in a Belgian warehouse. The U.S. government said the products were destroyed, but local authorities found them.

articles.title: Rubio Leads Charge in Trump’s New War in Latin America
articles.content: The secretary of state is shaping what could be the most consequential military actions of President Trump’s second term.

articles.title: California Wants to Ban ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Pans. These Chefs Say Don’t Do It.
articles.content: Rachael Ray and other food celebrities are speaking up in defense of nonstick pans. The actor Mark Ruffalo, who starred in a movie about the risky chemicals, is criticizing them.

articles.title: Jair Bolsonaro Is Convicted
articles.content: The 70-year-old former Brazilian president was sentenced to 27 years in prison for plotting a failed coup.

articles.title: Lawyers for Venezuelans Ask Court to Press D.H.S. on Temporary Protections
articles.content: A judge had ordered that Temporary Protected Status be kept in place, but Venezuelans who needed to re-register weren’t able to.

articles.title: $10 Million in Contraceptives Have Been Destroyed on Orders From Trump Officials
articles.content: The birth control pills, IUDs and hormonal implants were purchased by U.S.A.I.D. for women in low-income countries. They had been in limbo in a Belgian warehouse after the U.S. cut much of its foreign aid.

articles.title: U.S. Joins U.N. Security Council’s Criticism of Israeli Strike in Qatar
articles.content: The United States, ordinarily a protector of Israel at the United Nations, signed on to a statement condemning its attack on Hamas in the Qatari capital.

articles.title: Nepal’s Social Media Ban Backfires as Politics Moves to a Chat Room
articles.content: “The Parliament of Nepal right now is Discord,” a user said of the platform popular with video gamers, where tens of thousands are debating the nation’s future.

articles.title: The Manhunt for Charlie Kirk’s Killer
articles.content: The F.B.I. released two grainy images of a person of interest, but the gunman remained at large more than a day after the shooting.

articles.title: Carney Unveils Major Projects for Canada to Offset Damage of Trump’s Tariffs
articles.content: Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled big infrastructure plans. But they are likely to meet resistance from Indigenous and environmental groups.

articles.title: Brazil’s Supreme Court Is On Course to Convict Bolsonaro in Coup Plot
articles.content: A majority of voting justices said they plan to vote to convict Brazil’s former president of trying to hold onto power. A final verdict could come Thursday.

articles.title: On Ukraine and Gaza, Trump Casts Himself as a Bystander, if He Can’t Be a Peacemaker
articles.content: President Trump often insists he can bring peace to global conflicts. But when allies and adversaries alike appear to be ignoring him or testing American will, he adopts a what-can-you-do shrug.

articles.title: Belarus Frees 52 Political Prisoners and Gets a Warm Thank-You From Trump
articles.content: The release came as Aleksandr Lukashenko, the country’s authoritarian leader and an ally of President Vladimir Putin of Russia, seeks to normalize ties with the Trump administration.

articles.title: Charlie Kirk’s Influence Extended Far Beyond the U.S.
articles.content: The conservative activist had recently spoken at conferences in Asia. His message also resonated in Europe, and especially Britain, which has seen a rise in right-wing ideology.

articles.title: U.K. Ambassador to U.S., Peter Mandelson, Fired Over Epstein Links
articles.content: The British government said it withdrew the envoy after newly revealed emails showed the depth of his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.

articles.title: What Drove Israel’s Brazen Attack on Hamas in Qatar?
articles.content: Israeli officials and analysts say that revenge for the Hamas-led 2023 attack on Israel, and frustration over moribund Gaza truce negotiations, informed the decision to strike in Doha.

articles.title: Drone Barrage Over Poland Was a Test for NATO, and the U.S.
articles.content: A continent already on edge over the Ukraine war sees a Russian challenge to NATO readiness and to an America that wants to disengage from Europe.

articles.title: Russia’s Strategy Against the West: Escalate Slowly and See if It Responds
articles.content: Ukrainian and European officials say President Vladimir V. Putin has become emboldened by a lack of Western pushback.

articles.title: South Korean Leader Warns of U.S. Investments After Hyundai-LG Plant Raid
articles.content: President Lee Jae Myung made the comments as hundreds of South Korean workers swept in an immigration raid were flying home on Thursday.

articles.title: Nepal’s Young Protesters Find an Unlikely Partner: The Army
articles.content: After an explosion of popular rage tore through the country, its respected army was the only institution left standing. It’s now in talks with the protesters.

articles.title: How Macron Failed to Curb the Far Right
articles.content: As France drifted to the right, the president has tried to make the country more business-friendly and win back voters. His strategy hasn’t worked.

articles.title: Mexico City Gas Explosion Kills 8 and Injures at Least 90
articles.content: The cause of the enormous blast, which created chaos in one of the capital’s most heavily populated areas, was thought to be an accident.
